narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Better understanding of Korean grammar, vocabulary; speaking, listening, and writing skills
I further gained the grammatical, writing, and speaking skills to enhance my knowledge of the korean language.
Taking this course I further developed capabilities in speaking, reading, listening to and writing the Korean language.
I went over a lot of grammar I already knew, but was able to hone in on a lot and fix a lot of the smaller errors that I constantly did.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: The pace of the class was good, and there was always a lot of reinforcement for everything we learned (breakout rooms, assignments, practice in class). I also liked how assignments were graded for completion, not accuracy; it allowed us to make mistakes on new grammar concepts and get helpful feedback. Though a little strict at times, Choi SSN is a very kind and understanding teacher. Overall, the class is reasonable, not too difficult, and you do learn a good amount of Korean. Weaknesses: The class was not very organized, as a lot of time the course schedule was unclear, or assignment instructions were unclear, or I didn't know what vocabulary we were expected to know for a test/quiz. There would be a vocab document for each lesson, but it didn't seem like it was comprehensive. Also, the test format could definitely be improved in this virtual setting: screensharing the test and scrolling through questions was often frustrating, as we couldn't control the pace of the test and it was very inefficient overall. It would've been much better if she released the test as a pdf, so we do the test at an individual pace.
One strength of this course was the size. The student to faculty ratio was very small and enabled great personal relationships to grow.

The homeworks where we had to write sentences were really helpful for solidifying new grammar and vocabulary, and the only criticism I really have is that, toward the end of the course when we were writing our final presentations, we didn't have these homeworks and my rhythm of learning was a little messed up (I feel like this left me less prepared for the content of the unit 7-8 test).
Strengths~ Lots of time spent on practicing. Weakness~ A lot of homework, so it became a little overwhelming at some points.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: All of the practices in this course geared toward online learning were pretty successful.
At this point, I do not know.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, for anyone who is interested in improving their Korean skills.
Yes. I would highly reccomend. This course is great in regards to furthering and expanidng knowledge in korean language and culture.
